counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: No formula for gaining admission. Academic accomplishment is important, but admissions committee considers community involvement, leadership, distinction in extracurricular activities, and personal qualities and character.
counselor_perspectives.holistic_review: Relies on teachers, counselors, and alumni to share information about applicant's strength of character, ability to overcome adversity, and other personal qualities.
what_they_seek: Leadership and distinction in extracurricular activities
Students who will contribute to Harvard's mission
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_process: Applications discussed after initial review, candidates must stand out beyond just good test scores and grades
counselor_perspectives.memorable_candidates: Students with clear arc to their application: notable scientist, future political leader, bridge-builder in times of division

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Top 10% of graduating class minimum (vast majority)

test_scores.testing_requirement: SAT or ACT required. In exceptional cases when not accessible: AP, IB, GCSE, or National Leaving Exams accepted

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most rigorous courses available at high school, especially strong academic record
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Academic accomplishment in high school is important but not sufficient alone

essay_requirements.supplement_questions: Five required short-answer questions, 150 word limit each
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Ensure every student has same opportunity to reflect on life experiences, academic/extracurricular activities, how they will engage with others at Harvard, aspirations for future
what_makes_strong_essays: Clear vision for engagement at Harvard

extracurriculars.importance: Critical - distinction in extracurricular activities is key differentiator
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and distinction matter more than breadth
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership and community involvement highly valued
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show how activities demonstrate character and contribution to community
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Many admitted students have state or national-level recognition in their craft

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Letters from teachers, counselors, and alumni
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Harvard relies heavily on these to understand applicant beyond scores

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not explicitly stated as primary factor
demonstrated_interest.how_measured: Through essays, interviews, and engagement with Harvard community

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Discussion of each candidate after initial review, must stand out beyond academics
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic review considering academics, activities, personal qualities, recommendations
evaluation_rubrics.committee_process: Applications reviewed by admissions committee, consensus-based decisions

unique_insights: Harvard admits ~3% of applicants - most competitive in nation
Students who demonstrate deep passion, grit, and work ethic have best chances
Clear narrative arc in application is crucial: the notable scientist, the future leader, the bridge-builder
Test scores and grades are baseline filters, not sufficient for admission
Many admitted students are first-generation college students from diverse backgrounds
Cross-admit data: 62% of students admitted to both Harvard and Stanford choose Harvard
When given choice between Harvard and other top schools: 65% choose Harvard over Yale, 75% choose Harvard over Princeton
common_pitfalls: Being 'just' a well-rounded student with good scores
Not demonstrating impact or achievement beyond grades
Spreading activities too thin without depth

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: While grades and scores are important in understanding academic preparedness for MIT, it's really the match between applicant and the Institute that drives our selection process.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: MIT's mission is to use science, technology, and other areas of scholarship to make the world better. Community values excellence, openness, and fearless curiosity.

evaluation_factors.academic_preparedness: Must demonstrate readiness for fast-paced core curriculum and educational autonomy
evaluation_factors.noncognitive_indicators: Curiosity, initiative, resilience, ability to accept feedback, adaptability
evaluation_factors.character_qualities: Thoughtful people who take care of each other and lift each other up

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Top 10% of class (100% of admitted students who submitted class rank)

test_scores.testing_requirement: SAT or ACT required - reinstated after research showed need for students with least resources
test_scores.superscoring: Yes, MIT superscores both SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding courses available, especially in math and science. All students take foundational math/science regardless of major
academic_criteria.math_science_preparation: Critical - even humanities majors must take two semesters of physics

essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Show passion, alignment with MIT values, authentic voice
what_makes_strong_essays: Balance between academics and personal interests
essay_requirements.activity_description: Balance for the pleasure of it - MIT is NOT all work

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - evaluated on tier system
extracurriculars.tier_system: Tier 1 (exceptional, specialized like conducting prize-winning independent research) most competitive
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Quality over quantity - don't expect million things. Put heart into few things you truly care about
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Students apply theoretical knowledge to real-world problems, must show hands-on engagement
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Impact doesn't require curing diseases - tutoring a kid in math changes the world, advocating for change matters
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Hands-on makers, students who get 'metaphorically or literally' dirty trying something new

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: One from math/science teacher, one from humanities/social sciences/languages teacher
what_reviewers_look_for: Recent teacher who knows student well and likes them
Specific examples of achievements and contributions
Genuine insights into who student truly is
letters_of_recommendation.supplemental_recommendations: Not advised if from someone well-known but doesn't really know the student

demonstrated_interest.importance: Lower priority than fit and match
demonstrated_interest.interviews: MIT tries to interview all applicants with ~5,500 alumni interviewers, but not required. No campus interviews

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Application read by senior admissions officer holistically, strong applications read by additional officers who summarize for Admissions Committee
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: At least a dozen people significantly discuss and debate an application before admit pile
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Multiple groups of different admissions staff and faculty weigh in
key_evaluation_points: Match with MIT culture and mission

unique_insights: MIT's Latin motto 'Mens et Manus' (Mind and Hand) reflects hands-on philosophy
Innovation is risky and messy - MIT values students who embrace this
Community values are critical: thoughtful people who lift each other up
Reinstated testing requirement based on equity research - helps students with least resources demonstrate preparation
Students regularly work alongside faculty to shape MIT policies
Risk-taking can lead to failure, but structural supports help students learn resilience
MIT has active blogs since 2004, unfiltered student narratives
common_pitfalls: Focusing solely on academic achievement without showing hands-on making
Not demonstrating collaborative spirit or community care
Appearing to do activities just for resume building
Lacking balance between work and personal interests
Not showing resilience or willingness to take risks
Focusing on breadth over depth in activities
